This looks pretty much exactly how we do it in the `examples/pom.xml` for `examples/java8` module. https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/examples/pom.xml#L41

Minor tweak to match, then LGTM

LGTM for the HBaseIO part, I really wanted to use byte[] from the beginning since this is closer to the HBase API, but I kept it ByteString to be closer to the BigtableIO on Beam with the unintended protobuf conflict/exposure consequence. Now I consider that byte[] is a better thing than all the protobuf mess that the other alternative produces so :+1:

One extra comment about the other part of the PR, I thought also that another goal was not to expose  ByteString in the public API but we are still doing it, via the BigtableIO Write extends PTransform<PCollection<KV<ByteString, Iterable<Mutation>>>, PDone>.

I expected users to represent these ByteString as ByteBuffer, or byte[] as done now in HBaseIO, does this still make sense ? (and if you eventually decide to go with ByteBuffer for BigtableIO I would love that we have both BigtableIO and HBaseIO aligned in the representation).
Run Apex ValidatesRunner

Run Dataflow ValidatesRunner

Big table will still expose proto since that's already the user interface.
But big table isn't in the SDK core!
On Fri, Apr 14, 2017 at 22:50 Ismal Meja <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> One extra comment about the other part of the PR, I thought also that
> another goal was not to expose ByteString in the public API but we are
> still doing it, via the BigtableIO Write extends
> PTransform<PCollection<KV<ByteString, Iterable>>, PDone>.
>
> I expected users to represent these ByteString as ByteBuffer, or byte[] as
> done now in HBaseIO, does this still make sense ? (and if you eventually
> decide to go with ByteBuffer for BigtableIO I would love that we have both
> BigtableIO and HBaseIO aligned in the representation).
>

Understood, for the SDK core part, this is a great improvement.
One thing to consider for the future is that we are trying to encapsulate (shade is a part of this) most IOs to avoid leaking deps that produce dependency conflicts like guava or protobuf, but the GCP IOs seem to be the hardest to isolate since the main API of some of the IOs exposes guava or protobuf, it would be nice to consider to do this too for those IOs in the future, users running their own cluster can get into these problems when trying to integrate with the GCP IOs if we don't isolate this correctly, so maybe worth considering.

I found that the dependency analysis was ignoring test dependencies, to reproduce it just run on master:
```
mvn install -Dmaven.test.skip=true
```
It will complain on multiple modules on dependencies that should be scoped in test mode but arent currently.

This fixes the existing warnings when generating the javadoc.
For future reference, apparently javadoc in Java 8 has some issues to identify symbols on inner classes so it should be hinted about those..
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40928350/strange-javadoc-warning-can-find-method

Added:
- Infer `Coder`s from the types of the `Deserializer` using the registry
- Do not use explicit `withXxxCoder` in tests when not necessary
- Minimal tests for `Coder` inference

I have not added tests for `fromAvro/toAvro`.

An update:

The prior version of `google-cloud-spanner` was not compatible with Beam, which uses a newer version of gRPC (1.2.0). We are working with the teams that own those libraries to ensure that they only use stable APIs and thus are able to be compatible in the future.

There is a new (0.13-beta) version of this library that uses gRPC 1.2.0.
